Package provided.util

Class DaoBase

java.lang.Object
provided.util.DaoBase
Direct Known Subclasses:
ProjectDao
public abstract class DaoBase extends Object
This class contains utility methods for the DAO class.
Author:
Promineo

  • Method Details

    • startTransaction

      protected void startTransaction(Connection conn) throws SQLException
      This starts a MySQL transaction. Normally MySQL starts a transaction before every request and commits it after each request. By turning auto-commit off, the transaction is only committed when the application tells it to.
      Parameters:
      conn - The connection on which to start the transaction.
      Throws:
      SQLException - Thrown if an error occurs starting the transaction.

    • commitTransaction

      protected void commitTransaction(Connection conn) throws SQLException
      Commit the transaction. This will write all the changes, if any, to the database.
      Parameters:
      conn - The connection on which to commit the transaction.
      Throws:
      SQLException - Thrown if an error occurs committing the transaction.

    • rollbackTransaction

      protected void rollbackTransaction(Connection conn) throws SQLException
      Rolls back the changes so that nothing is committed.
      Parameters:
      conn - The connection on which to roll back the transaction.
      Throws:
      SQLException - Thrown if an error occurs rolling back the transaction.

    • setParameter

      protected void setParameter(PreparedStatement stmt, int parameterIndex, Object value, Class<?> classType) throws SQLException
      This sets a parameter on a prepared statement. If the parameter is null, it is handled correctly.
      Parameters:
      stmt - The prepared statement on which to set the parameter.
      parameterIndex - This is the one-based index of the parameter. In the SQL that is bound to the prepared statement, parameters are indicated by a question mark. From left-to-right, the index is the order in which a question mark is encountered.
      value - The parameter value. This may be null.
      classType - This is the Java class type of the parameter. It is used to select the correct method on the driver so that the parameter is added correctly. It is also used to set the type in case the parameter is null.
      Throws:
      SQLException - Thrown if an error occurs.

    • convertJavaClassToSqlType

      private int convertJavaClassToSqlType(Class<?> classType)
      Converts from a Java class to a java.sql.Types value.
      Parameters:
      classType - The class type
      Returns:
      A java.sql.Types value

    • getNextSequenceNumber

      protected Integer getNextSequenceNumber(Connection conn, Integer id, String tableName, String idName) throws SQLException
      This retrieves the number of child rows and adds one to the value. It is used to set the order of a child row. For a *real* application, a more sophisticated approach is desired. This method does not allow for entity reordering and does not allow for an entity to be deleted.
      Parameters:
      conn - The connection
      id - The ID of the parent entity
      tableName - The name of the table with the child rows
      idName - The name of the parent ID field
      Returns:
      The count of the entities attached to the parent plus one
      Throws:
      SQLException - Thrown if an error occurs.

    • getLastInsertId

      protected Integer getLastInsertId(Connection conn, String table) throws SQLException
      This returns the integer primary key value of the last row inserted into the given table. It allows the ID to be inserted into the entity object after inserting it into the table. The other way of doing this is to call Statement.getGeneratedKeys(), but this returns a result set that needs to be parsed for the ID. It's not really any easier than this approach but should be closer to database-agnostic.
      Parameters:
      conn - The connection
      table - The name of the table on which to get the last inserted primary key value
      Returns:
      The primary key value
      Throws:
      SQLException - Thrown if an error occurs

    • extract

      protected <T> T extract(ResultSet rs, Class<T> classType)
      This extracts an object of the given type from a result set. The object must have a zero-argument constructor. It builds an object from a result set using reflection as follows:
      1. The zero-argument constructor is obtained.
      2. An object of the given class type is created.
      3. A list of fields is obtained using reflection.
      4. The field name is converted from Java naming to SQL naming conventions (camel case to snake case). Obviously, for this to work, the Java name must match the column name. So, if the Java name is numServings, the column name must be num_servings.
      5. The value is assigned to the field in the object.
      Example: if a query returns values for a recipe, a Recipe object is returned. So: 
       String sql = "SELECT * from recipe";
 ResultSet rs = getResultSetSomehow();
 
 Recipe recipe = extract(rs, Recipe.class);
      Note: if the Java field does not exist in the result set, the value of the field is left unchanged. So, class Recipe has an instance variable: 
       List ingredients = new LinkedList<>();
      Since the result set does not contain a column named "ingredients", the value is left alone and the list initialization is preserved.
      Type Parameters:
      T - The Generic for the type of object to create and return.
      Parameters:
      rs - The result set in which to extract values. The result set must be positioned on the correct row by the caller.
      classType - The actual class type of the object to create.
      Returns:
      A populated class.

    • camelCaseToSnakeCase

      private String camelCaseToSnakeCase(String identifier)
      This converts a camel case value (rowInsertTime) to snake case (row_insert_time).
      Parameters:
      identifier - The name in camel case to convert.
      Returns:
      The name converted to snake case.
